title: Home
text: Professional Skills for Data Analytics is designed to enhance the professional capacity of students in data analytics. This module provides a comprehensive grounding in essential skills required for data literacy, bolstering existing skills and framing elements of best practice standards. It covers a range of topics including an introduction to R programming, an introduction to traditional statistical analysis and visualization, the creation of GitHub webpages to document and communicate analyses, and the use of Git and Markdown for reproducible practice.

title: Home
text: Professional Skills for Data Analytics is designed to enhance the professional capacity of students in data analytics. This module provides a comprehensive grounding in essential skills required for data literacy, bolstering existing skills and framing elements of best practice standards. It covers a range of topics including an introduction to R programming, an introduction to traditional statistical analysis and visualization, the creation of GitHub webpages to document and communicate analyses, and the use of Git and Markdown for reproducible practice.

title: Home
text:
Harper Adams Data Science

This module is a part of the MSc in Data Science for Global Agriculture, Food, and Environment at Harper Adams University, led by Ed Harris.

title: Home
text:
Module content

R Language: R language
Tidy data: Tidy data
Markdown and Github: Markdown and Github
Statistical reporting: Statistical reporting

title: Statisitical Analysis Report
text:
Importance of statistical analysis reports
Use cases: Business, Consultancy, Scientific Research
Objectives:

Guidelines for report creation
Tailor reports to the audience

title: Statisitical Analysis Report
text:
Understanding the Audience

Who is the report for?

Business managers, clients, scientists

Adjust technical depth based on their knowledge
What key information is expected by the audience?

title: Statisitical Analysis Report
section: Defining the Purpose of the Report
text:
Defining the Purpose of the Report

Clarify the objective: What are you solving or exploring?
Address the key questions or problems
Define the expected outcomes
For a very big analysis create a Statistical Analysis Plan

title: Statisitical Analysis Report
text:
Data Collection and Preparation

Overview of data:

Where did the data come from? How was it collected?

Data cleaning process:

Handling missing data, outliers, normalization

Importance of transparent data preprocessing

title: Statisitical Analysis Report
text:
Choosing the Right Statistical Methods

Criteria for selecting the correct statistical tests:

Parametric vs. Non-parametric

Common tests: T-tests, ANOVA, Regression
Match the method to the data type and objective

title: Statisitical Analysis Report
text:
Data Exploration & Visualization

Visualizing data using histograms, scatter plots, box plots
Summary statistics: Mean, Median, Standard Deviation
Highlight key trends or anomalies in the data

title: Statisitical Analysis Report
text:
Hypothesis Testing (If Applicable)

Define the null and alternative hypotheses
Statistical significance and p-values explained
Interpreting test results for non-technical stakeholders

title: Statisitical Analysis Report
text:
Regression Analysis (If Applicable)

Use of regression to explain relationships between variables
Key metrics: R-squared, Coefficients
Visualizing regression results with graphs

title: Statisitical Analysis Report
text:
Confidence Intervals

Importance of confidence intervals in analysis
How to interpret and explain them
Examples of 95% confidence intervals in real-world scenarios

title: Statisitical Analysis Report
text:
Correlation vs Causation

Correlation explained: Why it doesn’t mean causation
Avoid assumption of causality
Visualizations like correlation matrices help convey relationships

title: Statisitical Analysis Report
text:
Interpreting the Results

Key findings from the statistical analysis
How to explain technical results to non-technical stakeholders
Highlight the actionable insights

title: Statisitical Analysis Report
text:
Limitations and Assumptions

Discuss the limitations of the analysis:

Sampling bias, data quality, test assumptions

Why transparency is important
What can be done to mitigate limitations

title: Statisitical Analysis Report
text:
Visualizing Results

Best practices for choosing visualizations:

Charts, graphs, tables

Ensure clarity and simplicity
Use tools like Excel, R, Python for creating visuals

title: Statisitical Analysis Report
text:
Recommendations Based on the Analysis

Translating statistical results into actionable recommendations
Specific examples for business/scientific decisions:

Increase sales, improve efficiency, refine hypotheses

title: Statisitical Analysis Report
text:
Writing the Report

Typical components of a report:

Executive Summary
Methodology
Results
Discussion and Recommendations

Use plain language, avoid technical jargon

title: Statisitical Analysis Report
text:
Delivering the Report

Tailoring the delivery format:

PDF, PowerPoint, or interactive dashboards

Structuring the narrative for oral presentations
Tips for engaging non-technical audiences

title: Statisitical Analysis Report
text:
Common Pitfalls to Avoid

Avoid data overload or excessive jargon
Be cautious with misinterpretation of results
Always contextualize insights for the audience

title: Statisitical Analysis Report
section: Tools and Software for Statistical Reporting
text:
Tools and Software for Statistical Reporting

Tools overview:

R, Python, Quarto, Github, Excel, SPSS, Tableau

Choosing the right tool for your audience
Reproducibility

title: Statisitical Analysis Report
text:
Conclusion

Takeaway messages:

Clear communication is key
Tailor reports to the audience

Final thoughts and any questions?

title: Statistical Analysis Report
text:
This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com.
When you click the Knit button a document will be generated that includes both content as well as the output of any embedded R code chunks within the document. You can embed an R code chunk like this:

summary(cars)

     speed           dist       
 Min.   : 4.0   Min.   :  2.00  
 1st Qu.:12.0   1st Qu.: 26.00  
 Median :15.0   Median : 36.00  
 Mean   :15.4   Mean   : 42.98  
 3rd Qu.:19.0   3rd Qu.: 56.00  
 Max.   :25.0   Max.   :120.00

title: Statistical Analysis Report

This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com.
When you click the Knit button a document will be generated that includes both content as well as the output of any embedded R code chunks within the document. You can embed an R code chunk like this:

summary(cars)

     speed           dist       
 Min.   : 4.0   Min.   :  2.00  
 1st Qu.:12.0   1st Qu.: 26.00  
 Median :15.0   Median : 36.00  
 Mean   :15.4   Mean   : 42.98  
 3rd Qu.:19.0   3rd Qu.: 56.00  
 Max.   :25.0   Max.   :120.00

title: Schedule
text:
Harper Adams Data Science

This module is a part of the MSc in Data Science for Global Agriculture, Food, and Environment at Harper Adams University, led by Ed Harris.

title: Mini-project
text:
We have developed a new high-potential enhancer of biological nitrogen fixation (BNF) with nanotechnology which we believe can revolutionalise agriculture. It works by fostering long term relationships between beneficial soil microbes and plants. The technology works by affecting the gene expression of certain nitrogen-fixing bacteria such that they react to the presence of certain root exudates from a plant, and the presence of other bacteria that have been exposed to the same species in the past. This “wakes-up” dormant nitrogen fixing bacteria in a soil at an early crop growth stage, contributing to higher net BNF in the soil and better outcomes for the crop. Essentially, the nanotechnology builds a microbe-based memory system that allows for plants to be regrown in the same soil and with an enhanced chance of early BNF. We tested our nanotechnology against a no-treatment control and a regular BNF inoculant in randomized and replicated experiments with soya bean in 2016 and 2017. The experiments were randomized once, so the treatments occurred in the same exact plot in both years. The nanotechnology was only applied in 2016, so that we can examine if the effect lasts into 2017. Our hypothesis is that our treatment will outperform the regular BNF inoculant and the untreated control in yield in both years. We also hypothesise that the yield of the nanotechnology treatment on the same plot will improve in the second year. Finally, we believe that the regular BNF inoculation is still better than the control because these soils have poor nitrogen fixing bacteria due to excessive monocropping with cereals overtime.
Using the attached tidy data, please formulate appropriate null hypotheses to test our three alternate hypotheses. Conduct a statistical analysis based on the ANOVA technique and report whether our hypotheses are true or not. Conduct all the analysis in R and document the code comprehensively in a Quarto document.
Data

title: Mini-project
text:
We have developed a new high-potential enhancer of biological nitrogen fixation (BNF) with nanotechnology which we believe can revolutionalise agriculture. It works by fostering long term relationships between beneficial soil microbes and plants. The technology works by affecting the gene expression of certain nitrogen-fixing bacteria such that they react to the presence of certain root exudates from a plant, and the presence of other bacteria that have been exposed to the same species in the past. This “wakes-up” dormant nitrogen fixing bacteria in a soil at an early crop growth stage, contributing to higher net BNF in the soil and better outcomes for the crop. Essentially, the nanotechnology builds a microbe-based memory system that allows for plants to be regrown in the same soil and with an enhanced chance of early BNF. We tested our nanotechnology against a no-treatment control and a regular BNF inoculant in randomized and replicated experiments with soya bean in 2016 and 2017. The experiments were randomized once, so the treatments occurred in the same exact plot in both years. The nanotechnology was only applied in 2016, so that we can examine if the effect lasts into 2017. Our hypothesis is that our treatment will outperform the regular BNF inoculant and the untreated control in yield in both years. We also hypothesise that the yield of the nanotechnology treatment on the same plot will improve in the second year. Finally, we believe that the regular BNF inoculation is still better than the control because these soils have poor nitrogen fixing bacteria due to excessive monocropping with cereals overtime.
Using the attached tidy data, please formulate appropriate null hypotheses to test our three alternate hypotheses. Conduct a statistical analysis based on the ANOVA technique and report whether our hypotheses are true or not. Conduct all the analysis in R and document the code comprehensively in a Quarto document.
Data

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
Edit the following code so that the plot accurately reflects the axis labels and the subset functions returns an object with only the contents intended (as shown in the preceding comment to the function). Using indexing and regular expression tools in base R, extend the code to calculate the proportions of manual and automatic shift cars in the study

data(mpg)

# Scatter plot with base R
plot(mpg$disp1, mpg$hwy, col = as.factor(mpg$Year), 
     xlab = "Displacement", ylab = "Highway Miles per Gallon", pch = 19)
legend("topright", legend = unique(mpg$Year), col = unique(as.factor(mpg$Year)), pch = 19)

# Use base R to filter the data where cyl equals 8
subset(mpg, cy1 = '8')

Write pseudocode steps for calculating the volume of a cylinder (hint, if you do not know it by heart, you may need to research the equation for the volume of a cylinder!). For a cylinder of height = 3.2 cm and end radius of 5.5 cm, report the volume in cm to 2 decimal points of accuracy. Use at least 3 decimal points of accuracy for pi (hint, the quantity named pi is a standard variable in R!)
In your own words, what value is required for the d argument in the pwr.t.test() function in the {pwr} package? Show the code involved including any appropriate comment code required to answer this question. (hint: you will probably need to install the package, load it, and use help() on the function name)
Using the code chunk below, please answer the following questions:


What is the role of the set.seeed() function in the context of this code?
Why does calculating the mean of the copied original matrix return a numeric value while the mean of the same matrix when missing values are filled from the list returns NA?
Please fix the code sp that mean_of_original_copy and mean_matrix are equal

# Step 1: Create a 3x3 matrix with random numbers, and introduce NAs
set.seed(123) 
matrix_with_na <- matrix(sample(c(NA, 1:9), 9, replace = TRUE), nrow = 3)
copy_of_original<-matrix_with_na
matrix_with_na[1,2] <- NA  # Introduce 3 specific NAs
matrix_with_na[2,3] <- NA
matrix_with_na[3,1] <- NA


print("Original Matrix with NAs:")
print(matrix_with_na)

# Step 2: Create a list with the same structure but no NAs
list_with_values <- as.list(as.character(matrix(1:9, nrow = 3)))
print(list_with_values)

# Step 3: Use a for-loop to find the corresponding missing number from the list and fill the matrix
for (i in 1:3) {
  for (j in 1:3) {
    if (is.na(matrix_with_na[i,j])) {
      matrix_with_na[i,j] <- list_with_values[[(i-1)*3 + j]]  # Replace with corresponding value from list
    }
  }
}

print(matrix_with_na)

# Step 4: Try calculating the mean of the matrices
mean_matrix <- mean(matrix_with_na)
mean_of_original_copy <- mean(copy_of_original)
print(mean_of_original_copy)
print(mean_matrix)

Explain why this function is not working and return the working equivalent. Interpret what the estimate means and rank the species

# Load necessary package
install.packages('emmeans')
library(emmeans)

run_anova_posthoc <- function() {
  # Perform ANOVA on the iris dataset
  anova_result <- aov(Sepal.Length ~ Species, data = iris)
  
  # Perform post-hoc test using emmeans
  posthoc_result <- emmeans(anova_result, pairwise ~ Species)
  
  comparisons <- as.data.frame(posthoc_result$contrasts)
  
  print(comparisons)
  comparisons_df <- data.frame(Species = comparisons$species,
                               estimate = comparisons$estimate,
                               p.value = comparisons$p.value)
  
  return(comparisons_df)
}


run_anova_posthoc()

Using the iris dataset in R, conduct an anova of sepal length ‘by hand’ and report the F statistic. Feel free to use other packages for data wrangling/grouping only, but for each function used, appropriately comment on what it does and which package it comes from. Show your R code.
Write your own question similar in spirit, difficulty and scope to questions 3-6 above. Provide a full question including any code prompts. Also supply a full answer including any commented code required.
Write your own question similar in spirit, difficulty and scope to questions 3-6 above. Provide a full question including any code prompts. Also supply a full answer including any commented code required.

# Step 1: Create a 3x3 matrix with random numbers, and introduce NAs
set.seed(123) 
matrix_with_na <- matrix(sample(c(NA, 1:9), 9, replace = TRUE), nrow = 3)
copy_of_original<-matrix_with_na
matrix_with_na[1,2] <- NA  # Introduce 3 specific NAs

# Step 2: Create a list with the same structure but no NAs

# Step 3: Use a for-loop to find the corresponding missing number from the list and fill the matrix
for (i in 1:3) {

    if (is.na(matrix_with_na[i,j])) {
      matrix_with_na[i,j] <- list_with_values[[(i-1)*3 + j]]  # Replace with corresponding value from list
    }

print(matrix_with_na)

# Step 4: Try calculating the mean of the matrices

mean_of_original_copy <- mean(copy_of_original)

# Load necessary package
install.packages('emmeans')
library(emmeans)

run_anova_posthoc <- function() {
  # Perform ANOVA on the iris dataset
  anova_result <- aov(Sepal.Length ~ Species, data = iris)
  
  # Perform post-hoc test using emmeans
  posthoc_result <- emmeans(anova_result, pairwise ~ Species)
  
  comparisons <- as.data.frame(posthoc_result$contrasts)
  
  print(comparisons)
  comparisons_df <- data.frame(Species = comparisons$species,
                               estimate = comparisons$estimate,
                               p.value = comparisons$p.value)
  
  return(comparisons_df)
}


run_anova_posthoc()

Using the iris dataset in R, conduct an anova of sepal length ‘by hand’ and report the F statistic. Feel free to use other packages for data wrangling/grouping only, but for each function used, appropriately comment on what it does and which package it comes from. Show your R code.

title: Professional Skills for data science

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
William Sealy Gosset is credited with inventing the t-test while working for the Guinness brewery. The idea was refined and supported by the great statistician R. A. Fisher, and the idea was initially described in a paper anonymously by “Student”, in order to protect the commercial interests of Guinness. Today, it is perhaps one of the most prevalent and basic tools in statistics, and it is a fascinating story.




The question of the t-test
Data and assumptions
Graphing
Test and alternatives
Practice exercises

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
William Sealy Gosset is credited with inventing the t-test while working for the Guinness brewery. The idea was refined and supported by the great statistician R. A. Fisher, and the idea was initially described in a paper anonymously by “Student”, in order to protect the commercial interests of Guinness. Today, it is perhaps one of the most prevalent and basic tools in statistics, and it is a fascinating story.




The question of the t-test
Data and assumptions
Graphing
Test and alternatives
Practice exercises

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
2 The question of the t-test
The typical premise of the t-test is that it is used to compare populations you are interested in, which you measure with independent samples. There are a few versions of the basic question.

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
Compare two independent samples

Here you have measured a numeric variable and have two samples.
Are the means of the two samples different (i.e. did the samples come from different populations)?
Example: An experiment with a control and one treatment group.

title: Professional skills for data science
section: Compare 1 sample to a known mean
text:
Compare 1 sample to a known mean

Here you have one sample which you wish to compare to a mean value.
Did the sample come from a population exhibiting the known mean?
The data are simply a single numeric vector, and the population mean for comparison.

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
Paired samples

Here the individual observation comprising the 2 samples are not independent.
Example: Before vs After experiments
Another example: Measuring plots that are paired spatially
For each of these examples, there is a unit, patient, or plot identification, that represents the relationship of each paired measure.

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
3 Data and assumptions
The principle assumptions of the t-test are:

Gaussian distribution of observations WITHIN each sample
Heteroscedasticity (our old friend) - i.e., the variance is equal in each sample
Independence of observations

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
3.1 Evaluating and testing the assumptions

The t-test is thought to be somewhat robust to violation of assumptions
To a certain extent, Gaussian distribution and heteroscedasticiy assumption violations won’t bias your results.
The assumption of independence of observations is always of high importance.

title: Professional skills for data science
text: Testing assumptions

title: Professional skills for data science
section: Gaussian distribution of observations WITHIN each sample
text:
Gaussian distribution of observations WITHIN each sample

Plot and evaluate a a histogram (hist()) and a q-q plot (e.g., with qqplot())
Use a statistical test evaluating whether data are Gaussian (e.g., shapiro.test()
NB 1 test EACH SAMPLE SEPARATELY (this is sometimes confusing for beginners).

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
and If guilty?…

Mann-Whitney U-test will allow violation of assumptions
Also called the name Wilcoxon Test

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
Heteroscedasticity assumption

Examine graphically

# Bartlett's Test
bartlett.test(list(group1, group2))

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
Independence assumption

Can’t really be directly tested without supporting information
It’s up to you to ensure your analysis is being done on the right data
in time series and spatial data, you can test for autocorrelations (out of scope)

title: Professional skills for data science
section: typical Output of t test function.
text:
typical Output of t test function.

The t value; can be be positive or negative. The absolute value of t should increase with the probability that the samples came different populations.
The degrees of freedom; The number of independent data points available to estimate the t-statistic.
The 95% confidence interval; This gives a range of values that is likely to contain the true difference in means between the populations from which the samples were taken
The P-value

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
Indexing concept
Vectors, Matrices and arrays. Oh my!
Think of houses on a street
Each street has an address…

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
Indexing concept
Indexing
my_vector <- c(11.3, 11.2, 10.4, 10.4, 8.7, 10.8, 10.5, 10.3, 9.7, 11.2)
  
my_vector

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
Indexing concept
Vectors
my_vector        
my_vector[ ]     
my_vector[ 1:10]

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
Indexing concept
Matrices
my_matrix <- matrix(data = c(2,3,4,5,6,6,6,6), nrow = 2, byrow = T)
my_matrix[1:2,3:4]

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
Using which() and subsetting
A way to exploit indices
which(vector_a > 5)
which.min(vector_a)
which.max(vector_a)

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
Selection on data.frame objects

A data frame consists of variables (columns) and observations (rows)
All rows of a column are coerced to have the same data type
The columns are named
Accessing the contents of a data frame is again similar to accessing a matrix
what is the difference between a matrix and dataframe?

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
Slicing data
data(OrchardSprays)
OrchardSprays$treatment == "D"

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
Using aggregate()
Very useful to summarize your data
# NB use of list() and naming it "treatment"

aggregate(x = OrchardSprays$decrease, by = list(treatment = OrchardSprays$treatment), FUN = mean)

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
Basic data types in R

Concept of “Data Objects”
Data you can use is in the Global Environment
Data Type refers to the kind of data (important for computers)
Data Type is determined automatically in R (by the passive-aggressive Butler)
You often will need and want to tweak data type

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
Basic primitive types in R
a <- 1    # numeric
mode(a)
a <- "1"  # character
mode(a)
a <- '1'  # character
mode(a)
a <- TRUE # logical
mode(a)
a <-  1i # complex
mode(a)

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
Basic data types in R

NULL means undefined value (absence of a vector)

is.null() function can check it

NA means missing value (not available)

is.na()

inf means infinity e.g. 1/0 of -1/0

is.infinite()

NaN means an invalid number e.g. 0/0

is.nan()

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
Basic data types in R
my_list <- list(a = 1, b = 2)
my_list <- my_list$c  # Element 'c' doesn't exist, Output: NULL

na_addition  <- 5 + NA
print(na_addition)  # Output: NA

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
Basic data types in R
There are some rules for naming data objects

Can contain letters, numbers, some symbolic characters
Begin with a letter, Does not contain spaces
Some things are forbidden, @, %, #, etc.
Should be human-readable, consistent, and not too long

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
Basic data types in R
x1 <- 5  

x2 <- "It was a dark and stormy night" 

# hard to read
my_variable_9283467 <- 1

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
Data with factors


Let’s you want to analyse categorical data.
Sometimes this is called a “factor”.

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
Data with factors
Two types of factors

Non-ordered factors : the levels are the names of the categories cows = Martha, Ruth, Edith
Ordered factors: have a specific order dose = Control < Half < Full

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
class() and converting variables

# non-ordered factor
variety <- c("short", "short", "short",
             "early", "early", "early",
             "hybrid", "hybrid", "hybrid")

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
Vector and Matrix fun
Ways of organizing data


Vector - Homogeneous and One dimensional from 1 to i, my_vec[i]
Matrix - Two dimensions rows, columns, my_mat[i, j]
Array - Generalized matrix with n dimensions, my_array[i, j, k]

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
Vector and Matrix fun
# Vectors

myvec1 <- c(1,2,3,4,5) 
myvec1
class(myvec1) 

myvec2 <- as.character(myvec1)

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
Vector and Matrix fun
vec1 <- 1:16 
vec1 

mat1 <- matrix(data = vec1, 
               ncol = 4, 
               byrow = FALSE)

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
Lists
Unlike vectors and matrices, lists can hold elements of different types. Each element in a list can be a vector, matrix, data frame, or even another list
# Creating a list
my_list <- list(name="John", age=25, scores=c(90, 85, 88))
print(my_list)
You can access elements in a list using the $ operator or double square brackets [[]].

title: Professional skills for data science
text: Practice Exercises

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
Edit the following code so that the plot accurately reflects the axis labels and the subset functions returns an object with only the contents intended (as shown in the preceding comment to the function). Using indexing and regular expression tools in base R, extend the code to calculate the proportions of manual and automatic shift cars in the study

data(mpg)

# Scatter plot with base R
plot(mpg$disp1, mpg$hwy, col = as.factor(mpg$Year), 
     xlab = "Displacement", ylab = "Highway Miles per Gallon", pch = 19)
legend("topright", legend = unique(mpg$Year), col = unique(as.factor(mpg$Year)), pch = 19)

# Use base R to filter the data where cyl equals 8
subset(mpg, cy1 = '8')

Write pseudocode steps for calculating the volume of a cylinder (hint, if you do not know it by heart, you may need to research the equation for the volume of a cylinder!). For a cylinder of height = 3.2 cm and end radius of 5.5 cm, report the volume in cm to 2 decimal points of accuracy. Use at least 3 decimal points of accuracy for pi (hint, the quantity named pi is a standard variable in R!)
In your own words, what value is required for the d argument in the pwr.t.test() function in the {pwr} package? Show the code involved including any appropriate comment code required to answer this question. (hint: you will probably need to install the package, load it, and use help() on the function name)
Using the code chunk below, please answer the following questions:


What is the role of the set.seeed() function in the context of this code?
Why does calculating the mean of the copied original matrix return a numeric value while the mean of the same matrix when missing values are filled from the list returns NA?
Please fix the code sp that mean_of_original_copy and mean_matrix are equal

# Step 1: Create a 3x3 matrix with random numbers, and introduce NAs
set.seed(123) 
matrix_with_na <- matrix(sample(c(NA, 1:9), 9, replace = TRUE), nrow = 3)
copy_of_original<-matrix_with_na
matrix_with_na[1,2] <- NA  # Introduce 3 specific NAs
matrix_with_na[2,3] <- NA
matrix_with_na[3,1] <- NA


print("Original Matrix with NAs:")
print(matrix_with_na)

# Step 2: Create a list with the same structure but no NAs
list_with_values <- as.list(as.character(matrix(1:9, nrow = 3)))
print(list_with_values)

# Step 3: Use a for-loop to find the corresponding missing number from the list and fill the matrix
for (i in 1:3) {
  for (j in 1:3) {
    if (is.na(matrix_with_na[i,j])) {
      matrix_with_na[i,j] <- list_with_values[[(i-1)*3 + j]]  # Replace with corresponding value from list
    }
  }
}

print(matrix_with_na)

# Step 4: Try calculating the mean of the matrices
mean_matrix <- mean(matrix_with_na)
mean_of_original_copy <- mean(copy_of_original)
print(mean_of_original_copy)
print(mean_matrix)

Explain why this function is not working and return the working equivalent. Interpret what the estimate means and rank the species

# Load necessary package
install.packages('emmeans')
library(emmeans)

run_anova_posthoc <- function() {
  # Perform ANOVA on the iris dataset
  anova_result <- aov(Sepal.Length ~ Species, data = iris)
  
  # Perform post-hoc test using emmeans
  posthoc_result <- emmeans(anova_result, pairwise ~ Species)
  
  comparisons <- as.data.frame(posthoc_result$contrasts)
  
  print(comparisons)
  comparisons_df <- data.frame(Species = comparisons$species,
                               estimate = comparisons$estimate,
                               p.value = comparisons$p.value)
  
  return(comparisons_df)
}


run_anova_posthoc()

Using the iris dataset in R, conduct an anova of sepal length ‘by hand’ and report the F statistic. Feel free to use other packages for data wrangling/grouping only, but for each function used, appropriately comment on what it does and which package it comes from. Show your R code.
Write your own question similar in spirit, difficulty and scope to questions 3-6 above. Provide a full question including any code prompts. Also supply a full answer including any commented code required.
Write your own question similar in spirit, difficulty and scope to questions 3-6 above. Provide a full question including any code prompts. Also supply a full answer including any commented code required.

Using the code chunk below, please answer the following questions:


What is the role of the set.seeed() function in the context of this code?
Why does calculating the mean of the copied original matrix return a numeric value while the mean of the same matrix when missing values are filled from the list returns NA?
Please fix the code sp that mean_of_original_copy and mean_matrix are equal

# Step 1: Create a 3x3 matrix with random numbers, and introduce NAs
set.seed(123) 
matrix_with_na <- matrix(sample(c(NA, 1:9), 9, replace = TRUE), nrow = 3)
copy_of_original<-matrix_with_na
matrix_with_na[1,2] <- NA  # Introduce 3 specific NAs
matrix_with_na[2,3] <- NA
matrix_with_na[3,1] <- NA


print("Original Matrix with NAs:")
print(matrix_with_na)

# Step 2: Create a list with the same structure but no NAs
list_with_values <- as.list(as.character(matrix(1:9, nrow = 3)))
print(list_with_values)

# Step 3: Use a for-loop to find the corresponding missing number from the list and fill the matrix
for (i in 1:3) {
  for (j in 1:3) {
    if (is.na(matrix_with_na[i,j])) {
      matrix_with_na[i,j] <- list_with_values[[(i-1)*3 + j]]  # Replace with corresponding value from list
    }
  }
}

print(matrix_with_na)

# Step 4: Try calculating the mean of the matrices
mean_matrix <- mean(matrix_with_na)
mean_of_original_copy <- mean(copy_of_original)
print(mean_of_original_copy)
print(mean_matrix)

Explain why this function is not working and return the working equivalent. Interpret what the estimate means and rank the species

# Load necessary package
install.packages('emmeans')
library(emmeans)

run_anova_posthoc <- function() {
  # Perform ANOVA on the iris dataset
  anova_result <- aov(Sepal.Length ~ Species, data = iris)
  
  # Perform post-hoc test using emmeans
  posthoc_result <- emmeans(anova_result, pairwise ~ Species)
  
  comparisons <- as.data.frame(posthoc_result$contrasts)
  
  print(comparisons)
  comparisons_df <- data.frame(Species = comparisons$species,
                               estimate = comparisons$estimate,
                               p.value = comparisons$p.value)
  
  return(comparisons_df)
}


run_anova_posthoc()

Using the iris dataset in R, conduct an anova of sepal length ‘by hand’ and report the F statistic. Feel free to use other packages for data wrangling/grouping only, but for each function used, appropriately comment on what it does and which package it comes from. Show your R code.

title: Mini-project
text:
We have developed a new high-potential enhancer of biological nitrogen fixation (BNF) with nanotechnology which we believe can revolutionalise agriculture. It works by fostering long term relationships between beneficial soil microbes and plants. The technology works by affecting the gene expression of certain nitrogen-fixing bacteria such that they react to the presence of certain root exudates from a plant, and the presence of other bacteria that have been exposed to the same species in the past. This “wakes-up” dormant nitrogen fixing bacteria in a soil at an early crop growth stage, contributing to higher net BNF in the soil and better outcomes for the crop. Essentially, the nanotechnology builds a microbe-based memory system that allows for plants to be regrown in the same soil and with an enhanced chance of early BNF. We tested our nanotechnology against a no-treatment control and a regular BNF inoculant in randomized and replicated experiments with soya bean in 2016 and 2017. The experiments were randomized once, so the treatments occurred in the same exact plot in both years. The nanotechnology was only applied in 2016, so that we can examine if the effect lasts into 2017. Our hypothesis is that our treatment will outperform the regular BNF inoculant and the untreated control in yield in both years. We also hypothesise that the yield of the nanotechnology treatment on the same plot will improve in the second year. Finally, we believe that the regular BNF inoculation is still better than the control because these soils have poor nitrogen fixing bacteria due to excessive monocropping with cereals overtime.
Using the attached tidy data, please formulate appropriate null hypotheses to test our three alternate hypotheses. Conduct a statistical analysis based on the ANOVA technique and report whether our hypotheses are true or not. Conduct all the analysis in R and document the code comprehensively in a Quarto document.
Data

title: Mini-project
text:
We have developed a new high-potential enhancer of biological nitrogen fixation (BNF) with nanotechnology which we believe can revolutionalise agriculture. It works by fostering long term relationships between beneficial soil microbes and plants. The technology works by affecting the gene expression of certain nitrogen-fixing bacteria such that they react to the presence of certain root exudates from a plant, and the presence of other bacteria that have been exposed to the same species in the past. This “wakes-up” dormant nitrogen fixing bacteria in a soil at an early crop growth stage, contributing to higher net BNF in the soil and better outcomes for the crop. Essentially, the nanotechnology builds a microbe-based memory system that allows for plants to be regrown in the same soil and with an enhanced chance of early BNF. We tested our nanotechnology against a no-treatment control and a regular BNF inoculant in randomized and replicated experiments with soya bean in 2016 and 2017. The experiments were randomized once, so the treatments occurred in the same exact plot in both years. The nanotechnology was only applied in 2016, so that we can examine if the effect lasts into 2017. Our hypothesis is that our treatment will outperform the regular BNF inoculant and the untreated control in yield in both years. We also hypothesise that the yield of the nanotechnology treatment on the same plot will improve in the second year. Finally, we believe that the regular BNF inoculation is still better than the control because these soils have poor nitrogen fixing bacteria due to excessive monocropping with cereals overtime.
Using the attached tidy data, please formulate appropriate null hypotheses to test our three alternate hypotheses. Conduct a statistical analysis based on the ANOVA technique and report whether our hypotheses are true or not. Conduct all the analysis in R and document the code comprehensively in a Quarto document.
Data

function_name(argument_1 = value_1,

Arguments are like “settings” for functions
Each argument has a unique name
Arg values assigned by “=” and separated by “,”
“...” means there are optional args (ignore for now)

Question formulation and hypothesis testing
-“population of interest”
-samples and sampling
-test statistics
-null hypothesis
-Let’s talk about the P-value

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
Hypotheses: Null vs Alternative

Null Hypothesis (H₀):
The assumption that there is no effect or no difference.
Example: “There is no difference in test scores between two groups.”
Alternative Hypothesis (H₁ or Ha):
The assumption that there is an effect or a difference.
Example: “There is a difference in test scores between two groups.”

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
P-value: Definition and Interpretation

P-value:
The probability of obtaining results at least as extreme as the ones observed, under the assumption that the null hypothesis is true.
Interpretation:
A small p-value (typically < 0.05) suggests that the observed data is unlikely under the null hypothesis, leading to rejection of H₀.
A large p-value suggests that the data is consistent with the null hypothesis.

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
Question formulation and hypothesis testing
Benefits of NHST
-Familiar and acceptable to researchers
-Typically robust to assumptions
-Strong framework for evidence
-The basic idea is simple

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
Question formulation and hypothesis testing
Criticism of NHST
-Often interpreted under error
-Validation of analysis often neglected
-Education often deficient
-Practitioners ignorant of subtleties

title: Professional skills for data science
text:

-For presentation to others
-Creation of EVIDENCE to support CLAIMS
-Reproducible

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
ANalysis Of VAriance (ANOVA)

The analysis of variance is not a mathematical theorem, but rather a convenient method of arranging the arithmetic. R. A. Fisher (via Wishart 1934. Sppl. J. Roy. Soc. 1(1):26-61.)

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
1.1 Objectives

The question of 1-way ANOVA
Data and assumptions
Graphing
Test and alternatives
Practice exercises

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
ANOVA - When?
anova-able scenarios:

one numeric continuous dependent variable of interest
a factor that contains 2 or more levels, often with a control
When there are just two levels, it’s essentially a t-test

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
ANOVA - scenarios

overall difference At least one factor mean is different from the rest
Planned comparisons: Targeted orthogonal contrasts
post-hoc tests: compare any factors you want, with some correction.
Partition variation: What’s causing variance in the dependent variable?

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
Test statistic

The test statistic for ANOVA is the F ratio
It is the proportion of variance in the dependent variable between the groups, relative to that within the groups

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
Data and assumptions

data example: +experiment in animal genetics, looking at the weight of chickens (8-week old weight in grams), where weight is the continuous dependent variable. The factor is the sire identity; the chicks were sired by one of 5 sires, thus sire is a factor with 5 levels A, B, C, D, and E.

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
Long format data (preferred)

Convert your data to long format (aov in R works with long data)

weight <- c(A,B,C,D,E)
sire <- c(rep("A", 8),
          rep("B", 8),
          rep("C", 8),
          rep("D", 8),
          rep("E", 8) )
new.long<-data.frame(weight, sire)

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
Assumptions of ANOVA

Gaussian residuals (test graphically)
Homoscedasticity (test graphically, both overall and within factors; residuals versus fitted plot)
Independent observations (assumed)

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
Formal test of Gaussian residuals

We can use the shapiro NHST shapiro.test().

shapiro.test(rstandard(m1))

There is no evidence of difference to Gaussian in our residuals for our ANOVA model (Shapiro-Wilk: W = 0.99, n = 40, P = 0.99).

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
Homoscedasticity check
We will look at the residuals relative to the fitted values.
# Plot for homoscedasticity check
plot(formula = rstandard(m1) ~ fitted(m1),
     ylab = "m1: residuals",
     xlab = "m1: fitted values",
     main = "Spread similar across x?")
abline(h = 0,
       lty = 2, lwd = 2, col = "red")

# Make the mean residual y points (just to check)
y1 <- aggregate(rstandard(m1), by = list(new.long$Sire), FUN = mean)[,2]
# Make the x unique fitted values (just to check)
x1 <- unique(round(fitted(m1), 6))

points(x = x1, y = y1, 
       pch = 16, cex = 1.2, col = "blue")

title: Professional skills for data science
section: Bartlett test for equal variances between groups
text:
Bartlett test for equal variances between groups

bartlett.test(): do groups have signif different variances?
significant differences = homoskedasticity violated

bartlett.test(formula = weight~sire, data = new.long)

We find no evidence that variance in offspring weight differs between sires (Bartlett test: K-sqared = 1.69, df = 4, P = 0.79).

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
Graphing ANOVA
Recommended:  Boxplot, with some way to show the central tendency of the data separately for each factor level. For continuous variables, boxplots show this perfectly.

For count variables, barplots are sometimes used with the height set to the mean, along with some form of error bar.

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
Graphing ANOVA

boxplot(Weight ~ Sire, data = new.long,
        ylab = "Weight (g)",
        xlab = "Sire",
        main = "Effect of Sire on 8-wk weight",
        cex = 0) 

abline(h = mean(new.long$Weight), 
       lty = 2, lwd = 2, col = "red") # Mere vanity

points(x = jitter(rep(1:5, each = 8), amount = .1),
       y = new.long$Weight,
       pch = 16, cex = .8, col = "blue") # Mere vanity

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
ANOVA basic output

The ANOVA Table”

There are 2 rows;for the sire effect and the residual
The test statistic is the F value (1.87)
The P-value column is named “Pr(>F)” (0.14)
There are 4 degrees of freedom for the factor
Residual degrees of freedom is 35

No sig evidence that sire explains variation in weight

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
Contrasts and post hoc test

Let’s say that sire C is our reference level sire
For now, we’ll use lm() to compare everything to sire C
you can generate contrasts and make tests using emmeans e.t.c.
Let’s interpret the coefficients
What can we notice about the F value and p-value?

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
Post hoc tests

The phrase post hoc implies an afterthought. Tread carefully
When multiple tests are made on the same data, it increases the chance of discovering a false positive (Type I error)
p-values can be adjusted to keep Type I error chance at 5%.

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
Bonferroni

The Bonferroni adjustment of p-values:

Simply divides the P by the number of post hoc pairwise comparisons, so you end up evaluating at a lower P-value
It is considered conservative, and there are alternatives.

alternatives exists e.g. Tukey’s e.t.c.
With pairwise.t.test(), the output will be a matrix of p-values

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
Tukey HSD (Honestly Significant Differences)

The Tukey HSD test is less conservative Bonferroni
We use the Tukey.HSD() function to apply it here.
Also note that the p-values tend to be smaller for the exact same comparisons, but there are sill no significant comparisons.

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
Alternatives amidst assumption violations
In case the assumptions of 1-way ANOVA cannot be met by the data, there are a few options:

Transformations (log(), sqrt() e.t.c.)
GLMs
Non-parameteric tests: a great escape, but tend to have less power

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
Kruskal-Wallis alternative to the 1-way ANOVA
# Try this:
# ?kruskal.test
kruskal.test(formula = Weight ~ Sire,
             data = new.long)

The result is qualitatively the same as that for our 1-way ANOVA test

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
ANOVA calculation details
# Our data
chicken.wide

For the ANOVA code in the script, try to follow what is going on in the code
It is okay if not every detail is clear yet
Do we get the same answer as aov()?

title: Problem set
text:
Edit the following code so that the plot accurately reflects the axis labels and the subset functions returns an object with only the contents intended (as shown in the preceding comment to the function). Using indexing and regular expression tools in base R, extend the code to calculate the proportions of manual and automatic shift cars in the study

data(mpg)

# Scatter plot with base R
plot(mpg$disp1, mpg$hwy, col = as.factor(mpg$Year), 
     xlab = "Displacement", ylab = "Highway Miles per Gallon", pch = 19)
legend("topright", legend = unique(mpg$Year), col = unique(as.factor(mpg$Year)), pch = 19)

# Use base R to filter the data where cyl equals 8
subset(mpg, cy1 = '8')

Write pseudocode steps for calculating the volume of a cylinder (hint, if you do not know it by heart, you may need to research the equation for the volume of a cylinder!). For a cylinder of height = 3.2 cm and end radius of 5.5 cm, report the volume in cm to 2 decimal points of accuracy. Use at least 3 decimal points of accuracy for pi (hint, the quantity named pi is a standard variable in R!)
In your own words, what value is required for the d argument in the pwr.t.test() function in the {pwr} package? Show the code involved including any appropriate comment code required to answer this question. (hint: you will probably need to install the package, load it, and use help() on the function name)
Using the code chunk below, please answer the following questions:


What is the role of the set.seeed() function in the context of this code?
Why does calculating the mean of the copied original matrix return a numeric value while the mean of the same matrix when missing values are filled from the list returns NA?
Please fix the code such that mean_of_original_copy and mean_matrix are equal

# Step 1: Create a 3x3 matrix with random numbers, and introduce NAs
set.seed(123) 
matrix_with_na <- matrix(sample(c(NA, 1:9), 9, replace = TRUE), nrow = 3)
copy_of_original<-matrix_with_na
matrix_with_na[1,2] <- NA  # Introduce 3 specific NAs
matrix_with_na[2,3] <- NA
matrix_with_na[3,1] <- NA


print("Original Matrix with NAs:")
print(matrix_with_na)

# Step 2: Create a list with the same structure but no NAs
list_with_values <- as.list(as.character(matrix(1:9, nrow = 3)))
print(list_with_values)

# Step 3: Use a for-loop to find the corresponding missing number from the list and fill the matrix
for (i in 1:3) {
  for (j in 1:3) {
    if (is.na(matrix_with_na[i,j])) {
      matrix_with_na[i,j] <- list_with_values[[(i-1)*3 + j]]  # Replace with corresponding value from list
    }
  }
}

print(matrix_with_na)

# Step 4: Try calculating the mean of the matrices
mean_matrix <- mean(matrix_with_na)
mean_of_original_copy <- mean(copy_of_original)
print(mean_of_original_copy)
print(mean_matrix)

Explain why this function is not working and return the working equivalent. Interpret what the estimate means and rank the species

# Load necessary package
install.packages('emmeans')
library(emmeans)

run_anova_posthoc <- function() {
  # Perform ANOVA on the iris dataset
  anova_result <- aov(Sepal.Length ~ Species, data = iris)
  
  # Perform post-hoc test using emmeans
  posthoc_result <- emmeans(anova_result, pairwise ~ Species)
  
  comparisons <- as.data.frame(posthoc_result$contrasts)
  
  print(comparisons)
  comparisons_df <- data.frame(Species = comparisons$species,
                               estimate = comparisons$estimate,
                               p.value = comparisons$p.value)
  
  return(comparisons_df)
}


run_anova_posthoc()

Using the iris dataset in R, conduct an anova of sepal length ‘by hand’ and report the F statistic. Feel free to use other packages for data wrangling/grouping only, but for each function used, appropriately comment on what it does and which package it comes from. Show your R code.
Write your own question similar in spirit, difficulty and scope to questions 3-6 above. Provide a full question including any code prompts. Also supply a full answer including any commented code required.
Write your own question similar in spirit, difficulty and scope to questions 3-6 above but involving the creation nested lists and indexing of elements from within the deepest nest. the list must have more than 2 levels of nesting and no names. Provide a full question including any code prompts. Also supply a full answer including any commented code required.

title: Problem set
text:
Edit the following code so that the plot accurately reflects the axis labels and the subset functions returns an object with only the contents intended (as shown in the preceding comment to the function). Using indexing and regular expression tools in base R, extend the code to calculate the proportions of manual and automatic shift cars in the study

data(mpg)

# Scatter plot with base R
plot(mpg$disp1, mpg$hwy, col = as.factor(mpg$Year), 
     xlab = "Displacement", ylab = "Highway Miles per Gallon", pch = 19)
legend("topright", legend = unique(mpg$Year), col = unique(as.factor(mpg$Year)), pch = 19)

# Use base R to filter the data where cyl equals 8
subset(mpg, cy1 = '8')

Write pseudocode steps for calculating the volume of a cylinder (hint, if you do not know it by heart, you may need to research the equation for the volume of a cylinder!). For a cylinder of height = 3.2 cm and end radius of 5.5 cm, report the volume in cm to 2 decimal points of accuracy. Use at least 3 decimal points of accuracy for pi (hint, the quantity named pi is a standard variable in R!)
In your own words, what value is required for the d argument in the pwr.t.test() function in the {pwr} package? Show the code involved including any appropriate comment code required to answer this question. (hint: you will probably need to install the package, load it, and use help() on the function name)
Using the code chunk below, please answer the following questions:


What is the role of the set.seeed() function in the context of this code?
Why does calculating the mean of the copied original matrix return a numeric value while the mean of the same matrix when missing values are filled from the list returns NA?
Please fix the code such that mean_of_original_copy and mean_matrix are equal

# Step 1: Create a 3x3 matrix with random numbers, and introduce NAs
set.seed(123) 
matrix_with_na <- matrix(sample(c(NA, 1:9), 9, replace = TRUE), nrow = 3)
copy_of_original<-matrix_with_na
matrix_with_na[1,2] <- NA  # Introduce 3 specific NAs
matrix_with_na[2,3] <- NA
matrix_with_na[3,1] <- NA


print("Original Matrix with NAs:")
print(matrix_with_na)

# Step 2: Create a list with the same structure but no NAs
list_with_values <- as.list(as.character(matrix(1:9, nrow = 3)))
print(list_with_values)

# Step 3: Use a for-loop to find the corresponding missing number from the list and fill the matrix
for (i in 1:3) {
  for (j in 1:3) {
    if (is.na(matrix_with_na[i,j])) {
      matrix_with_na[i,j] <- list_with_values[[(i-1)*3 + j]]  # Replace with corresponding value from list
    }
  }
}

print(matrix_with_na)

# Step 4: Try calculating the mean of the matrices
mean_matrix <- mean(matrix_with_na)
mean_of_original_copy <- mean(copy_of_original)
print(mean_of_original_copy)
print(mean_matrix)

Explain why this function is not working and return the working equivalent. Interpret what the estimate means and rank the species

# Load necessary package
install.packages('emmeans')
library(emmeans)

run_anova_posthoc <- function() {
  # Perform ANOVA on the iris dataset
  anova_result <- aov(Sepal.Length ~ Species, data = iris)
  
  # Perform post-hoc test using emmeans
  posthoc_result <- emmeans(anova_result, pairwise ~ Species)
  
  comparisons <- as.data.frame(posthoc_result$contrasts)
  
  print(comparisons)
  comparisons_df <- data.frame(Species = comparisons$species,
                               estimate = comparisons$estimate,
                               p.value = comparisons$p.value)
  
  return(comparisons_df)
}


run_anova_posthoc()
